articles.title: Understanding HTML Basics
content: HTML, or HyperText Markup Language, is the standard markup language used to create web pages. It forms the backbone of all websites and serves as the foundation for web development.
Each HTML document is made up of elements, which are defined by tags. These tags tell the browser how to display content, such as headings, paragraphs, links, images, and more.

To get started with HTML, you'll need a text editor and a basic understanding of how HTML tags work. As you progress, you can explore more advanced topics, such as forms, multimedia, and accessibility.

articles.title: CSS for Beginners
content: CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, is a stylesheet language used to control the presentation of web pages. It allows developers to separate content from design, making websites more visually appealing and easier to maintain.
CSS works by applying styles to HTML elements. These styles can include colors, fonts, spacing, and layout properties. CSS can be written inline, embedded within a

By learning CSS, you can transform plain HTML documents into beautiful, responsive websites. Start with basic selectors and properties, then move on to advanced topics like animations and media queries.

articles.title: JavaScript: The Starting Point
content: JavaScript is a powerful programming language that enables interactivity on web pages. With JavaScript, you can create dynamic content, such as interactive forms, image sliders, and real-time data updates.
JavaScript can be written directly within an HTML document or linked as an external file. It interacts with the Document Object Model (DOM) to manipulate web page elements.

If you're new to JavaScript, start with the basics, such as variables, functions, and events. As you gain confidence, explore libraries and frameworks like React or Vue.js to build more complex web applications.
